neighbors.name: Andy F Bensend
neighbors.claims: Andy F. Bensend operates over 4,000 acres of corn and soybeans in Barron County, using no-till and other sustainable practices and running a custom farming and agronomy business ([www.morningagclips.com](https://www.morningagclips.com/wis-farmer-wins-conservation-award/#:~:text=Over%20the%20years%2C%20Bensend%20has,agronomy%20and%20nutrient%20management%20planning)). He serves as vice-president of the Wisconsin Soybean Marketing Board and often hosts field days to share conservation techniques with fellow farmers ([wisoybean.org](https://wisoybean.org/bean-bros-wisconsin-soy-growers-bridge-generations/#:~:text=young%20employee%20learning%20from%20Bensend,currently%20serves%20as%20vice%20president)) ([www.farmprogress.com](https://www.farmprogress.com/conservation-and-sustainability/sharing-soil-success#:~:text=Image%3A%20Wisconsin_20farmer3png,this%20approach%20by%20demonstrating%20them)). Bensend was honored with the American Soybean Association’s 2017 National Conservation Legacy Award for his leadership in sustainable farming ([www.morningagclips.com](https://www.morningagclips.com/wis-farmer-wins-conservation-award/#:~:text=The%20American%20Soybean%20Association%20,Courtesy%20of%20American%20Soybean%20Association)).
neighbors.influence_justification: State ag leader; large farm operator

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a peer farmer or conservation specialist approach Bensend, highlighting aspects of the project that preserve soil health and water quality.

neighbors.name: Carl & Madisen Hagen
neighbors.claims: Carl and Madisen Hagen jointly own a rural parcel in Barron County but maintain a very low public profile ([www.barroncountywi.gov](https://www.barroncountywi.gov/index.asp?SEC=D8CFD154-5CE4-4DE3-A2EC-CAC2E08FBDB6#:~:text=View%20,Schedule%20of%20Meetings)). No references to the Hagens were found in local meeting records or news, suggesting they have not publicly voiced any stance on development ([www.barroncountywi.gov](https://www.barroncountywi.gov/index.asp?SEC=D8CFD154-5CE4-4DE3-A2EC-CAC2E08FBDB6#:~:text=View%20,Schedule%20of%20Meetings)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach personally and informally to build rapport; listen to their questions and provide straightforward information, since they have no known stance yet.

neighbors.name: Steven J Bensend
neighbors.claims: Steven J. Bensend is Andy Bensend’s brother and a co-owner of the family land in Barron County, though he resides in Prescott, Wisconsin, outside the area ([drydenwire.com](https://drydenwire.com/obituaries/donna-l-bensend/#:~:text=She%20is%20survived%20by%20sons%2C,Hill%2C%20and%20Jordan%20McDonald)). He has been involved as an alumni advisor for an agricultural fraternity at UW–River Falls, but he holds no known roles in Barron County civic affairs ([wisoybean.org](https://wisoybean.org/bean-bros-wisconsin-soy-growers-bridge-generations/#:~:text=Bensend%E2%80%99s%20brother%2C%20Steven%2C%20is%20the,shared%20a%20lot%20of%20commonalities)) ([drydenwire.com](https://drydenwire.com/obituaries/donna-l-bensend/#:~:text=She%20is%20survived%20by%20sons%2C,Hill%2C%20and%20Jordan%20McDonald)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage via his brother Andy or another trusted local peer; emphasize respect for their family’s farm legacy and keep him updated as an absentee owner.

neighbors.name: Darleen P Vergin
neighbors.claims: Darleen P. Vergin is an older landowner rooted in a family that has farmed near Dallas, Wisconsin for generations ([drydenwire.com](https://drydenwire.com/obituaries/ronald-vergin/#:~:text=He%20was%20born%20July%2030%2C,to%20his%20cabin%2Fhome%20in%20Barnes)). She has no recorded involvement in local government or media discussions, indicating an absence of public stance on development issues ([www.barroncountywi.gov](https://www.barroncountywi.gov/index.asp?SEC=D8CFD154-5CE4-4DE3-A2EC-CAC2E08FBDB6#:~:text=View%20,Schedule%20of%20Meetings)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach gently through a familiar community member; emphasize respect for her family’s land legacy and reassure that the project will not disrupt the area’s rural character.

neighbors.name: Gregory W Thompson
neighbors.claims: Gregory W. Thompson holds numerous land parcels in Barron County, but unlike other Thompson family members long established in the Dallas area, he does not appear in local civic records or news outlets ([farm.ewg.org](https://farm.ewg.org/top_recips.php?fips=55005&page=5&progcode=total_cr#:~:text=109%20%20,%2414%2C152)) ([northwoodsreporter.com](https://northwoodsreporter.com/stories/569167773-who-were-the-indefinitely-confined-voters-in-barron-county#:~:text=Kearney%20Nell%20Thompson%20%20,09%2F18%2F2020)). His public profile is minimal, with no documented statements on development or community issues ([northwoodsreporter.com](https://northwoodsreporter.com/stories/569167773-who-were-the-indefinitely-confined-voters-in-barron-county#:~:text=Kearney%20Nell%20Thompson%20%20,09%2F18%2F2020)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Major acreage owner; low public engagement

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage directly with clear, businesslike communication; address any contractual or land-use questions he may have, as he tends to keep a low profile.

neighbors.name: Alan P. & Julie K. Amundson
neighbors.claims: Alan P. Amundson (born 1931) passed away in early 2018 ([www.legacy.com](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/legacyremembers/name-obituary?pid=188120832#:~:text=Alan%20Amundson%20Obituary%20%281931%20,Alan%20was%20born)). Neither Alan nor Julie is mentioned in available town or county records as holding any public role or activism in local affairs ([northwoodsreporter.com](https://northwoodsreporter.com/stories/569167773-who-were-the-indefinitely-confined-voters-in-barron-county#:~:text=Darla%20Susan%20Amundson%20%20,09%2F18%2F2020)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Maintain a respectful, personal approach (possibly via family contacts), given their low public involvement.

neighbors.name: Peter D. & Sarah M. Etlicher
neighbors.claims: The Etlicher family has farmed in Barron County for decades—Marlyn W. Etlicher (1942–2021) ran a dairy farm near Barron for 42 years ([drydenwire.com](https://drydenwire.com/obituaries/marlyn-etlicher/#:~:text=Almena,for%2059%20lovely%20years)). No public statements or offices held by Peter or Sarah Etlicher were found in local news or records ([northwoodsreporter.com](https://northwoodsreporter.com/stories/569167773-who-were-the-indefinitely-confined-voters-in-barron-county#:~:text=No%20,etlicher)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach through agricultural community connections and stress how project plans respect farming land and livelihoods.

neighbors.name: Lee Ann Wirth
neighbors.claims: The Wirths are a longstanding local family: the late DeWayne E. Wirth (1942–2022) of Prairie Farm raised a family in the area, including a son residing in Dallas, WI ([www.legacy.com](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/leadertelegram/name/dewayne-wirth-obituary?id=36623260#:~:text=match%20at%20L68%20DeWayne%20is,laws%3A%20Bonnie%20%28Paul%29%20Krahenbuhl%20of)). There is no indication that Lee Ann Wirth has taken any public stance or role in local development issues (her name is absent from accessible civic records) ([northwoodsreporter.com](https://northwoodsreporter.com/stories/569167773-who-were-the-indefinitely-confined-voters-in-barron-county#:~:text=No%20,wirth)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Longtime local family, no official role

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage via trusted community members or family friends, emphasizing respect for rural character and farmland continuity.

neighbors.name: Richard W. Lentz
neighbors.claims: The Lentz family has run a dairy farming operation near Dallas, WI since the 1960s ([www.legacy.com](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/leadertelegram/name/leondra-lentz-obituary?id=32006334#:~:text=match%20at%20L61%20from%20Barron,H%2C%20FFA%20and%20Junior%20Holsteins)). Richard W. Lentz himself received about $11,155 in USDA farm subsidies in 2021 (down from $24,740 in 2020) ([northwoodsreporter.com](https://northwoodsreporter.com/stories/655167150-did-farm-subsidies-in-cities-associated-with-barron-county-rise-or-fall-in-2021#:~:text=Richard%20W.%20Lentz%20%20,49.1)), underscoring his active agricultural role.

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a fellow respected farmer or agricultural extension contact him, highlighting how the project can coexist with and even support long-term farmland preservation and the family’s legacy.

neighbors.name: Lucas & Stephanie Nease
neighbors.claims: Lucas and Stephanie Nease purchased a 3,732-sqft, 4-bed home in Ridgeland, WI in April 2024 ([www.homes.com](https://www.homes.com/property/152-16th-st-ridgeland-wi/ms9qf73xkgyhb/#:~:text=4%20Beds%204%20Baths%203%2C732,Value)) ([www.homes.com](https://www.homes.com/property/152-16th-st-ridgeland-wi/ms9qf73xkgyhb/#:~:text=Date%20Name%20Owned%20For%20Owner,Type)). Having acquired their property in 2024, the Neases are relatively new to the area ([www.homes.com](https://www.homes.com/property/152-16th-st-ridgeland-wi/ms9qf73xkgyhb/#:~:text=Date%20Name%20Owned%20For%20Owner,Type)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Welcome them with friendly, informal outreach through a neighborly introduction, and be prepared to listen openly to any questions or concerns they might have.

neighbors.name: Robert J Rogers
neighbors.claims: Robert J. “Bob” Rogers serves as the District 1 representative on the Barron County Board of Supervisors ([www.change.org](https://www.change.org/decision-makers/bob-rogers-barron-county-board-of-supervisors-district-1#:~:text=Change,District%201%20District%201%2C%20Wisconsin)). He voted in favor of a 2024 county resolution endorsing a broadband expansion project (22–3 vote) to improve local infrastructure ([citizenportal.ai](https://citizenportal.ai/articles/6392941/Barron-County/Wisconsin/Barron-County-Board-approves-software-purchase-dam-repairs-forest-work-plan-and-other-measures-broadband-endorsement-draws-three-no-votes#:~:text=,the%20resolution%20carried)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage through formal channels, acknowledging his leadership role. Emphasize how the project respects local decision-making and can bolster the community (e.g., tax base, services), aligning with the county’s development goals.

neighbors.name: Dylan Sandwick
neighbors.claims: Dylan Sandwick has no evident public profile or documented views in local records or media ([www.transfermarkt.com](https://www.transfermarkt.com/dylan-barnett/spieleGegeneinander/spieler/264190#:~:text=,Dylan%20Thorntorn%20Dylan%20Watts%20%C3%89anna)). Aside from being listed as a landowner near Ridgeland, no information on his background or stance is readily available ([www.transfermarkt.com](https://www.transfermarkt.com/dylan-barnett/spieleGegeneinander/spieler/264190#:~:text=,Dylan%20Thorntorn%20Dylan%20Watts%20%C3%89anna)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Use a personalized, low-key approach (e.g., a casual in-person visit) to introduce the project and invite conversation, since he has not voiced any public opinions.

neighbors.name: Allen R Schutz
neighbors.claims: Allen R. Schutz is a veteran farmer in the Dallas area of Barron County, having received about $350,000 in farm subsidy payments since 1995 ([farm.ewg.org](https://farm.ewg.org/top_recips.php?fips=55005&page=4&progcode=total#:~:text=93%20%20,%24341%2C766)). This places him among the top 100 farm-subsidy recipients in the county (ranked #93 in 1995–2024) ([farm.ewg.org](https://farm.ewg.org/top_recips.php?fips=55005&page=4&progcode=total#:~:text=93%20%20,%24341%2C766)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach via a trusted agricultural peer or local farm network. Emphasize respect for his farmland (e.g., minimal disruption and soil conservation) and explain how the project can coexist with, or even benefit, long-term farm use.

neighbors.name: Village Of Ridgeland
neighbors.claims: See ORG table.

neighbors.name: Arne & Elizabeth Thompson
neighbors.claims: Arne and Elizabeth Thompson own multiple agricultural parcels in the Town of Dallas, Barron County ([sfs.dpi.wi.gov](https://sfs.dpi.wi.gov/safr_ro/tax_apportionment_all_districts.asp?year=2015#:~:text=Barron%2003%20028%20T,00)). They have no recorded involvement in local government or public comments on development, indicating a low public profile ([northwoodsreporter.com](https://northwoodsreporter.com/stories/655167150-did-farm-subsidies-in-cities-associated-with-barron-county-rise-or-fall-in-2021#:~:text=Orin%20J.%20Thompson%20%20,49.2)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a respected neighboring farmer or community elder reach out, emphasizing how the project can coexist with farming traditions and preserve rural heritage.

neighbors.name: Charles G & Renee M Rihn
neighbors.claims: Charles G. Rihn is part of a multi-generation farming family; records show a Melvin C. Rihn farming in the Bloomer area since the 1940s ([www.legacy.com](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/leadertelegram/name/denese-rihn-obituary?id=9707238#:~:text=Bloomer%20Denese%20E,grandchildren%2C%20other%20relatives%20and%20friends)). Charles and Renee Rihn themselves do not appear in Barron County meeting minutes or local news reports, suggesting no active public profile ([northwoodsreporter.com](https://northwoodsreporter.com/stories/655167150-did-farm-subsidies-in-cities-associated-with-barron-county-rise-or-fall-in-2021#:~:text=No%20,rihn)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Out-of-town farm owners; no local roles

approach_recommendations.engage: Connect via a mutual farming community contact (possibly through Bloomer area networks) to reassure them that the project will not diminish their land’s agricultural value or use.

neighbors.name: Not Available
neighbors.claims: Barron County’s land records list the owner of parcel 020350008000 as “Not Available,” indicating no individual name on record ([www.usvotefoundation.org](https://www.usvotefoundation.org/town-of-dallas-barron-county-wi-election-office#:~:text=Town%20of%20Dallas%2C%20Barron%20County%2C,contact%20information%20for%20the%20election)). Without an identified owner, there is no public background or stated position to assess for this parcel ([www.usvotefoundation.org](https://www.usvotefoundation.org/town-of-dallas-barron-county-wi-election-office#:~:text=Town%20of%20Dallas%2C%20Barron%20County%2C,contact%20information%20for%20the%20election)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Work through county channels or nearby landowners to locate and engage this owner once their identity is known, addressing any concerns with transparency.

neighbors.name: Tyler J Graetz
neighbors.claims: A wedding announcement shows Tyler J. Graetz planning a marriage in August 2024 in nearby Cadott, Wisconsin ([www.zola.com](https://www.zola.com/wedding/sikoragraetzwedding#:~:text=Jessica%20Sikora%20and%20Tyler%20Graetz%27s,ZOLA)). Beyond that personal note, no public records or media references tie Graetz to any civic activities or opinions on local development ([northwoodsreporter.com](https://northwoodsreporter.com/stories/569167773-who-were-the-indefinitely-confined-voters-in-barron-county#:~:text=No%20,graetz)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach informally through a peer in his age group or community circle to discuss any concerns about noise or property impacts, highlighting the project’s minimal disruption to his plans.

neighbors.name: Travis & Jolene Lentz
neighbors.claims: Travis J. Lentz is a prominent local farmer, receiving $79,103 in federal farm subsidies in 2020 alone ([northwoodsreporter.com](https://northwoodsreporter.com/stories/655167150-did-farm-subsidies-in-cities-associated-with-barron-county-rise-or-fall-in-2021#:~:text=Dairyland%20Trucking%2C%20LLC%20%20,12.9)). Neither Travis nor Jolene Lentz has a record of speaking at public hearings or in news on development issues ([northwoodsreporter.com](https://northwoodsreporter.com/stories/569167773-who-were-the-indefinitely-confined-voters-in-barron-county#:~:text=Freida%20Agusta%20Lentz%20%20,09%2F19%2F2020)), suggesting they have not taken a public stance in such debates.

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage them via local agricultural leaders or the county extension agent, focusing on how the project will protect soil/drainage and not impede farm operations or road access.

neighbors.name: Barry L & Alicia M Wirth
neighbors.claims: Barry L. Wirth and Alicia M. Wirth jointly own multiple rural land parcels in Barron County, Wisconsin ([gcswebportal.co.barron.wi.us](https://gcswebportal.co.barron.wi.us/Search.aspx?ParcelNumber=012310029010#:~:text=No%20Property%20Addresses%20were%20found)). No records were found of the Wirths holding public office or making statements on local development issues ([northwoodsreporter.com](https://northwoodsreporter.com/stories/569167773-who-were-the-indefinitely-confined-voters-in-barron-county#:~:text=No%20,wirth)). Barron County has emphasized farmland preservation since 1979 ([www.barroncountywi.gov](https://www.barroncountywi.gov/index.asp?DE=DA744D5F-9BCC-4150-81FC-9F75BB477217&SEC=5849F663-F197-46AF-9020-7123068F82DF#:~:text=WI%20www,Working%20Lands%20Initiative%20became%20state)), suggesting that landowners like the Wirths prioritize agricultural use of their property.

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach via a fellow local farmer to discuss how the project will protect long-term soil health and preserve farmland use, directly addressing any concerns about erosion or runoff.

neighbors.name: Ian R Thompson
neighbors.claims: Ian R. Thompson is listed as the owner of multiple land parcels in Barron County’s property records ([gcswebportal.co.barron.wi.us](https://gcswebportal.co.barron.wi.us/Search.aspx?ParcelNumber=012310029010#:~:text=No%20Property%20Addresses%20were%20found)). While other Thompson family members appear in local listings (e.g., a Kearney N. Thompson in Dallas) ([northwoodsreporter.com](https://northwoodsreporter.com/stories/569167773-who-were-the-indefinitely-confined-voters-in-barron-county#:~:text=Kearney%20Nell%20Thompson%20%20,09%2F18%2F2020)), no public references specifically to Ian R. Thompson were found in news or civic archives. Barron County’s longstanding farmland preservation program ([www.barroncountywi.gov](https://www.barroncountywi.gov/index.asp?DE=DA744D5F-9BCC-4150-81FC-9F75BB477217&SEC=5849F663-F197-46AF-9020-7123068F82DF#:~:text=WI%20www,Working%20Lands%20Initiative%20became%20state)) indicates that local landowners like Thompson tend to be mindful of keeping land in agricultural use.

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a community agriculture liaison reach out to highlight how the development plans include soil conservation measures and eventual land restoration, addressing typical farming community concerns about preserving productive land.

neighbors.name: Robert & Leondra Lentz Revocable Trust
neighbors.claims: See RESIDENT table.
neighbors.influence_justification: Longtime local farming family; no notable public office or large economic influence

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage Robert “Bob” Lentz (trustee) in a personal conversation emphasizing respect for their farm legacy and assuring the project will not harm their land interests

neighbors.name: Jennie-O Turkey Store Inc
neighbors.claims: Jennie-O Turkey Store Inc., a subsidiary of Hormel Foods, operates a major turkey processing plant in Barron, Wisconsin ([www.wctrib.com](https://www.wctrib.com/business/production-changes-planned-next-year-at-jennie-o-plant-in-wisconsin#:~:text=Jennie,from%20parent%20company%20Hormel%20Foods)). Local turkey farms supply this facility, contributing over $120 million annually to Barron County’s economy, while the plant itself adds more than $1 billion ([www.wpr.org](https://www.wpr.org/agriculture/barron-county-officials-take-economic-impact-bird-flu#:~:text=According%20to%20the%20University%20of,Dave%20Armstrong%20said%20the%20bird)). The company is one of the area’s largest employers and agribusiness stakeholders ([www.wpr.org](https://www.wpr.org/agriculture/barron-county-officials-take-economic-impact-bird-flu#:~:text=According%20to%20the%20University%20of,Dave%20Armstrong%20said%20the%20bird)). No record of public opposition to developments by Jennie-O was found, as its focus remains on maintaining stable operations and supply chains.
neighbors.influence_justification: Major agribusiness (Hormel subsidiary) with ~$1 billion local economic impact and extensive employment

approach_recommendations.engage: Coordinate with Jennie-O’s corporate affairs or plant management to ensure the project poses no risk to their operations; emphasize potential mutual benefits (e.g., improved infrastructure or energy reliability) to secure neutrality or support

neighbors.name: Alicia M & Barry L Wirth Joint Revocable Trust
neighbors.claims: See RESIDENT table.
neighbors.influence_justification: Private landowners with no known broader influence in business or politics

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach Alicia and Barry Wirth personally to discuss the project; address any concerns about land use changes and highlight any benefits or safeguards to ease potential opposition

neighbors.name: Blaine E & Vivian J Whitmore Revocable Trust
neighbors.claims: See RESIDENT table.
neighbors.influence_justification: Elderly farming couple; no public leadership roles or significant economic reach beyond their farm

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage Blaine and Vivian Whitmore with a neighborly, transparent approach; reassure them the project will respect their property and minimize any disruption to their daily life or land use

neighbors.name: Alexander W & Mary J Olson Revocable Trust
neighbors.claims: See RESIDENT table.
neighbors.influence_justification: Large-scale farm operators with extensive landholdings; financially significant locally, though not public officials

approach_recommendations.engage: Meet directly with Alexander Olson (primary trustee) to understand his plans or concerns; emphasize how the project can coexist with or even benefit his farming operation, potentially through lease income or infrastructure improvements

neighbors.name: Jerry L Nicolle L Emmert Living Trust
neighbors.claims: See RESIDENT table.
neighbors.influence_justification: Insufficient public evidence to assess community influence (private farming family; no known public office or major local roles)

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage trustee Jerry Emmert directly; emphasize the project’s compatibility with farming and conservation (e.g., erosion control, water quality benefits) to resonate with his values ([www.wispolitics.com](https://www.wispolitics.com/2022/western-wisconsin-conservation-council-farmer-to-farmer-conversations-shorten-path-to-conservation-success/#:~:text=Emmert%20has%20been%20integrating%20conservation,place%20and%20improving%20water%20quality)). One-on-one outreach is key, as his stance is not publicly known.

neighbors.name: Peter & Jacqueline Amundson Family Trust
neighbors.claims: See RESIDENT table.
neighbors.influence_justification: No public information indicating significant community influence (family landholders with private profile)

approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out personally to Peter and Jacqueline Amundson to understand their perspective. Provide assurances that the project will respect their property’s value and rural character, since their stance is not publicly documented.

neighbors.name: Douglas L Wirth Revocable Trust
neighbors.claims: See RESIDENT table.
neighbors.influence_justification: No public evidence of community leadership or influence (private individual landowner)

approach_recommendations.engage: Initiate a personal conversation with Douglas Wirth about the project. Emphasize respect for his land interests and address any concerns about land-use changes, given that he has no known public stance.

overview_summary: None of the five neighbors have a documented stance on the development (0 support, 0 oppose, 5 unknown). One high-profile neighbor (a prominent conservation farmer) holds significant influence, while the others show medium to low community influence with limited public engagement. None of these four neighboring landowners have a documented stance on development (all noted stances are unknown). Most appear to have low public profiles in the community. Only one neighbor – a multi-parcel dairy farmer – shows moderate local influence. All profiled neighbors have an **unknown** stance on development (no explicit public position found). One is a high-influence local official (Rogers, a county supervisor), another is a medium-influence large-scale farmer (Schutz), and the rest appear to have low community influence. None of the five profiled neighbors have taken a documented public stance on local development or clean energy projects. All are classified as having an unknown position due to lack of explicit statements. Community influence appears limited – none are current officials or outspoken civic leaders, with any local sway coming mostly from their status as landowners rather than formal roles. Neither of the two profiled neighbors has made a public stance on the development, leaving both classified as "unknown" in their support or opposition. Both landowners appear to have limited formal roles or public engagement, meaning the cohort includes no high-influence community figures (both are low-influence local residents). Among the neighboring landowners, four are family trusts of local farmers indicating long-held agricultural properties, and one is a major agribusiness. The family trusts (Lentz, Wirth, Whitmore, Olson) represent private individuals with substantial farmland but no corporate structure, so their development stance is personal and not publicly documented. The sole corporate neighbor is Jennie-O Turkey Store Inc., a Hormel Foods subsidiary operating a large turkey processing plant; it has significant economic influence but has shown no overt position on outside developments. No competitors or known organized opposition groups were identified in this neighbor set, though the farming families may be motivated to preserve land value and rural character, and the corporation will prioritize protecting its operations. All three neighboring landowners are listed as living or family trusts, indicating individual or family farm ownership rather than corporate entities ([www.wispolitics.com](https://www.wispolitics.com/2022/western-wisconsin-conservation-council-farmer-to-farmer-conversations-shorten-path-to-conservation-success/#:~:text=Jerry%20Emmert%20and%20his%20brother%2C,farm%20in%20the%20late%201990s)). One trustee, Jerry Emmert, is a third-generation farmer known for conservation-oriented practices in western Wisconsin ([www.wispolitics.com](https://www.wispolitics.com/2022/western-wisconsin-conservation-council-farmer-to-farmer-conversations-shorten-path-to-conservation-success/#:~:text=Jerry%20Emmert%20and%20his%20brother%2C,farm%20in%20the%20late%201990s)) ([www.wispolitics.com](https://www.wispolitics.com/2022/western-wisconsin-conservation-council-farmer-to-farmer-conversations-shorten-path-to-conservation-success/#:~:text=Emmert%20has%20been%20integrating%20conservation,place%20and%20improving%20water%20quality)). The other trusts (Amundson and Wirth) have no notable public profile or documented stance on development; they likely view their land as a family asset and farmland to preserve ([abcdocz.com](https://abcdocz.com/doc/662118/wisconsin-farmers-union-news#:~:text=into%20the%20%E2%80%9CBig%20Tent,the%20good%20work%20of%20supporting)).
